terms.definition: Software as a Service - a cloud-based software delivery model where applications are hosted by a provider and accessed via the internet
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides answers to common questions and solutions to problems
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, ensuring users always access the most current version
A unified system for storing, organizing, and managing all documents in a single location accessible to authorized users
An organized collection of digital documents, resources, and materials stored electronically for easy access and retrieval
Digital documentation that includes engaging elements like quizzes, assessments, and multimedia to enhance user comprehension
A defined sequence of steps or processes that automate and standardize how tasks are completed within a system
Software or services that are hosted on remote servers and accessed via the internet rather than installed locally
A visual interface that displays key metrics, data, and insights in an organized, easy-to-read format for quick decision-making
The systematic monitoring and documentation of adherence to regulations, standards, and policies within an organization
Occupational Safety and Health Administration - the U.S. federal agency that sets and enforces workplace safety standards
International Organization for Standardization - a global body that develops and publishes international standards for various industries
A systematic process of identifying, analyzing, and evaluating potential hazards or threats in a workplace or system
The formal process of documenting, tracking, and analyzing workplace accidents, near-misses, or safety violations
The ability of a system or platform to handle increased workload, users, or data without compromising performance
